Q1.1:
This is a survey conducted for academic research purposes by researchers from Harvard University and the OECD. It will take approximately 25 minutes to complete. The survey data is used for research purposes only, and the research is non-partisan. You will be compensated for this survey if you complete the survey and your responses pass our survey quality checks. These checks use statistical control methods to detect incoherent and rushed responses. It is very important for the validity of our research that you answer honestly and read the questions carefully before answering.

 

You should know the following: The survey collects personal data, including socio-demographic characteristics and political views. All of the answers you provide will remain anonymous and be treated with absolute confidentiality. The personal data we collect will be transferred and stored on secure servers. Only researchers working on the project will have access to the anonymized data. Your participation in this survey is completely voluntary. You are entitled to choose not to take part. If at first you agree to take part, you can later change your mind. Your decision will not be held against you in any way. Your refusal to participate will not result in any consequences or any loss of benefits that you are otherwise entitled to receive. You can ask any questions before you decide whether to participate.  

 

If you have questions, concerns, or complaints, or think the research has offended you, you can contact the research team at social.economics.research2020@gmail.com or call the Harvard University Area Institutional Review Board (“IRB”) at (617) 496-2847. The OECD is committed to protecting the personal data it processes, in accordance with its Personal Data Protection Rules (https://www.oecd.org/general/data-protection.htm). If you have further queries or complaints related to the processing of your personal data, please contact the Data Protection Officer (DPO@oecd.org). If you need further assistance in resolving claims related to personal data protection you can contact the Data Protection Commissioner (DPC@oecd.org).


 
Do you agree to participate in the survey?

Q19.1:
To fight global warming, the U.S. federal government could implement a policy package to reduce emissions, for example by investing in clean technologies (renewable energy, electric vehicles, public transport, more efficient insulation, etc.). 
The funding for these investments could be collected annually through an additional individual contribution for the foreseeable future. Assume that everyone in the U.S. as well as citizens of other countries would be required to contribute according to their means.
How much would you at most be willing to pay annually through an additional individual contribution to limit global warming to safe levels (less than 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit)?
Q19.2_4:
By taking this survey, you are automatically entered into a lottery to win $100. In a few days you will know whether you have been selected in the lottery. The payment will be made to you in the same way as your compensation for this survey, so no further action is required on your part. 

  
You can also donate a part of this additional compensation (should you be selected in the lottery) to a reforestation project through the charity The Gold Standard. This charity has already proven effective to reduce 151 million tons of CO2 to fight climate change and has been carefully selected by our team. The Gold Standard is highly transparent and ensures that its projects featured the highest levels of environmental integrity and contribute to sustainable development. 

 
  Should you win the lottery, please enter your donation amount using the slider below: - Donation amount (in U..S. dollars)
Q20.2_4: At which level(s) do you think public policies to tackle climate change need to be put in place? (Multiple answers are possible) - Global
Q20.2_3: At which level(s) do you think public policies to tackle climate change need to be put in place? (Multiple answers are possible) - Federal
Q20.2_2: At which level(s) do you think public policies to tackle climate change need to be put in place? (Multiple answers are possible) - State
Q20.2_1: At which level(s) do you think public policies to tackle climate change need to be put in place? (Multiple answers are possible) - Local
Q20.3: Do you agree or disagree with the following statement: "The U.S. should take measures to fight climate change."
Q20.4_1: How should U.S. climate policies depend on what other countries do? - If other countries do more, the U.S. should do...
Q20.4_2: How should U.S. climate policies depend on what other countries do? - If other countries do less, the U.S. should do...
Q20.5_1:
To achieve a given reduction of greenhouse gas emissions globally, costly investments are needed.
 
Ideally, how should countries bear the costs of fighting climate change? - Countries should pay in proportion to their income
Q20.5_2:
To achieve a given reduction of greenhouse gas emissions globally, costly investments are needed.
 
Ideally, how should countries bear the costs of fighting climate change? - Countries should pay in proportion to their current emissions
Q20.5_3:
To achieve a given reduction of greenhouse gas emissions globally, costly investments are needed.
 
Ideally, how should countries bear the costs of fighting climate change? - Countries should pay in proportion to their past emissions (from 1990 onwards)
Q20.5_4:
To achieve a given reduction of greenhouse gas emissions globally, costly investments are needed.
 
Ideally, how should countries bear the costs of fighting climate change? - The richest countries should pay it all, so that the poorest countries do not have to pay anything
Q20.5_5:
To achieve a given reduction of greenhouse gas emissions globally, costly investments are needed.
 
Ideally, how should countries bear the costs of fighting climate change? - The richest countries should pay even more, to help vulnerable countries face adverse consequences: vulnerable countries would then receive money instead of paying
Q20.6: Do you support or oppose establishing a global democratic assembly whose role would be to draft international treaties against climate change? Each adult across the world would have one vote to elect members of the assembly.
Q20.7:
Imagine the following policy: a global tax on greenhouse gas emissions funding a global basic income.


Such a policy would progressively raise the price of fossil fuels (for example, the price of gasoline would increase by 40 cents per gallon in the first years). Higher prices would encourage people and companies to use less fossil fuels, reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Revenues from the tax would be used to finance a basic income of $30/month to each human adult, thereby lifting the 700 million people who earn less than $2/day out of extreme poverty. Most Americans would lose out financially as they would face price increases in excess of $30/month.


Do you support or oppose such a policy?
Q20.8: Do you support or oppose a tax on all millionaires around the world to finance low-income countries which comply with international standards regarding climate action? This would finance infrastructure and public services such as access to drinking water, healthcare, and education.

Q5.2:
The United States government should strongly encourage the development of renewable fuel sources while decreasing the use of fossil fuels.  It should, for example, offer rebates to people who buy things like solar panels or electric cars.  

It should also offer programs to people who work in the fossil fuel energy to help them transition to a more sustainable career.  For example, it could offer training programs to coal miners that would help them switch careers.  It could also offer retirement packages to older coal miners.

The federal government could also help fund scientists who are studying climate change and ways to combat it.

The United States government should base their decisions on scientific evidence -- and most of that evidence points to climate change being very real.  They should look for ways to make the transition process as easy for people as possible.  The aforementioned coal miners, for example, will need ways to support themselves as their mines close.

Q5.2: Addressing climate change must be a research and policy priority. Associated concerns with high ecosystem risk (e.g. changes to Earth's magnetic field) must also be given priority.  Research must be publicly funded and must preclude influence by politics or other vested interests. Private citizens and small businesses must be offered incentives to directly reduce their carbon footprint and develop the capacity to go off grid in emergencies. Because innovative quality and freedom are of the essence, existing and emerging survival technologies must be regulated to protect against monopolistic forces. We must partner with less developed nations to involve their scientists and leaders in the survival initiative and ensure that existing and emerging technologies are shared equitably.

Q25.2:
I enjoyed the videos, however as an ADD individual my recall for exact numbers even over relatively short time lapses, is very poor. I know my responses are probably not accurate.

In theory, all of the proposed policy changes will be beneficial.  However, partial or unfairly targeted implementations (e.g. higher gasoline prices or automobile noncompliance penalties WITHOUT targeted redistribution) will hurt the working poor and true middle class a great deal. One percenters are masters at passing the bill 
for infrastructure and other tax funded amenities (which benefit them disproportionately) to the rest of us. Making sure they can't dodge their proportionate share of the cost will be a herculean effort.

Roll back the tax holiday the millionaire sector has enjoyed since Cheney/Reagan. Use those funds to repair and rebuild infrastructure using green technologies.  

Incent businesses to implement work from home throughout their organizations-- imagine the carbon emissions reduction! Not to mention the health and work-life balance benefits. (No excuses, COVID 19 has made it clear that this measure is entirely workable for most office and professional employees.) 

Move toward more distance learning for higher grade level students, reducing both emissions and school-based bullying. Younger children can benefit from more space and smaller class sizes. (In fact, let's move away altogether from the warehousing approach to education.)

We need national regulations with teeth to shut down public forum lying by commission or omission, with the highest penalties up to and including imprisonment for public office holders. (I've heard that UK may provide a good benchmark. Do we need a Constitutional Amendment--Freedom from BS and Betrayal of Public Trust?) If public forum lying is not addressed posthaste, good luck trying to move forward on climate change at anything above an agonizing crawl.

Q5.2:
The U.S. Federal Gov't should do what they were doing under President Trump. A slow steady non-detrimental approach to gradually improving our power grid to some more alternative energy platforms but NOT doing it too quickly like CA who has rolling blackouts.  Also maintain the U.S. energy independence through fossil fuels and natural gas.  We maintain our power in the world by doing so.  NO GREEN NEW DEAL!  IT WON"T WORK and will destroy our country.  Also it is an utter JOKE to say our planet has 8 more years or 10 more years.  Ralph Nader said the same thing 40 years ago and GOSH we are still here with cleaner air and water than ever before.  Finally, if China and India and other industrialized nations don't do what we are doing at the same time what we do will MEAN NOTHING!!!  Oh BTW even if we were to wipe the United States off the face of the world map eliminating 100% of its pollution it would only decrease the temperature by .4  degrees & one volcanic eruption such as the one occurring in Italy right this minute wipes out the entire world's green efforts 
Check the studies!

Q25.2:
The programs discussed here will do several things:
1)  destroy America financially
2)  allow other countries (China specifically) to overtake America financially and militarily in just a few years
3)  destroy the poorer people and middle class because ALL of these proposals will come with HEAVY taxation that will hurt these two classes the most BY FAR.  The subsidies they would receive is the Gov't paying these people back their own tax money; the $600 is NOTHING compared to the added expense these people will have to pay as a result of these idiotic ideas policies

The policies make the assumption that all world players contribute: good fucking luck getting that to happen.  China will use this stupidity to simply take over sooner.  They will say they are going to comply like they did before.  OH by the way since the Paris Climate Accord was discussed China built in excess of 250 coal fired power plants.  Guess they didn't get the message.  They pollute FAR more than we ever will.  

The U.S. does more than any other nation to make the environment clean for ALL people.  The problem is India, China, even the EU do really give a shit about being serious on the environment UNLESS WE PAY FOR IT!

One other elephant in the room.  alternative power sources create massive pollution problems down stream.  Wind turbines destroy the environment: kill 1000's of birds including endangered species, the create disorientation in fish when built in or near waterways (check Norway study) disrupting the electrical flow in the water making fish change their migration patterns and making some species stop spawning.  HMMM big issue!   Electric cars: how do you dispose of the batteries? They are a significant pollutant and no one wants to mention that.  Nuclear would be better but no one wants to say that either.

Your entire survey was a crock of bull shit!  Nice sales pitch:  oh let's subsidize people lets give everyone money to offset their added cost due to our plans, lets eliminate all world poverty!  WOW what a load of crap!

Q25.2: I have to live (if you can call it that) on $700.00/month, despite the fact I worked 35 years as an engineer & librarian. I am elderly, disabled & live alone in a rural mountain community. There is no public transportation, my survival depends on my vehicle. What you propose is tantamount to giving me a death sentence. If you put ANOTHER gas tax in California, we'd end of paying $20.00 a gallon! Since NO rebate could possibly happen till the END of the year, us low income would starve & be homeless long before we saw any money. How about this proposal: for those that are below poverty level, have a vehicle exchange program. I'll turn in my gasoline-powered vehicle for an electric/hybrid/solar/hydrogen...etc., powered vehicle. At $40k (minimum) the government can supply me with a vehicle! Also, ''Organic" is the biggest scam on the planet--like my mother says: ''Prove it!''.

Also, not only companies but governments are to blame for the sorry state of our climate due to inaction, unreasonable goals, lack of international cooperation.  Individuals, likewise, are responsible and some take it seriously with recycling, limited or no car use, more use of public transportation.  But man individuals are also deniers that there is even climate change that is destroying so much of our world's air, land, and seas.  Donald Trump, for example, set the USA back too many years with his ignorance, lack of curiosity, destructive policies, deregulation, etc. etc. etc.  Fortunately, people like Bill Gates is helping sound the alarm for all to pay attention to the issue.

Q3.4: Almost or at least daily
Q5.2: Climate change is an acceleration of natural processes by human behavior. Any considerations need to reduce the impact of humans, protect wildlife and land, and ensure that those countries that have not yet reached the same level of prosperity (so called third world countries) are not unduly harmed by these restrictions. The causes of climate change are still being debated, but some causes are well know, such as the use of fossil fuels. The government should reduce the number and value of subsidies to gas and oil companies, while increasing funds for solar, wind, nuclear, and other alternative energy sources---especially for innovations which improve the efficiency or efficacy of the sources. Food products, such as corn, should NOT be turned into fuels, at least not while there are still people experiencing food insecurities. The government should ensure that environmental regulations support the phasing out of older, more polluting technologies and their replacement with more environmentally friendly options.

Q5.2:
My main consideration is the many ways that certain segments of our city could use instead of driving. For example, train, bus, etc.. we have some of the worse transportation. So when the government talks and has implemented certain rules for vehicles, ( no rust, tire tread, gas mileage, etc,) that leaves very few who are either poor or lower to middle class.

So to tell people we must reduce our carbon prints to better the climate changes happening, they're not talking about socio-econmically lower wage earners.

How can they say, " stop using plastic?" when many of these people in poorer areas have actual uses for them. Not only that, but instead they offer, ( for a price,) paper bags. I don't care if the paper is recycled, it's still having an effect on trees, which obviously we need.

Q25.2:
Within our city, about 15 yrs ago the R.E.C. ( Regoinal Environental Center,) started gardens in poor neighborhoods, also teaching people about food insecurity & how to make it less so & at the same time people were shown what chemicals farmers typically use that harm & have been harming the global world. 

These neighborhoods were shown what to use instead to grow their own foods & also how to use natural products, instead of chemicals for every day cleaning. 

It's a non-profit org. They "hire" interns, starting w/ teens and higher ages who learn and then spread their new knowledge into their individual communities. They learn things they would not have learned if not being involved. They also started limiting their consumption of meats, beefs, chicken, etc...knowing now how farming these animals has harmed the world. I think these are much better ways to get people to help lower the global warming. No taxes, no extra money. Just learning the truth and acting on those truths. Great survey!!
